comments.commentBody: Russiagate is much bigger than Watergate! The Republicans either step up and get an independent investigation started or they will feel the wrath of the American people heat up to volcanic levels!

The whole discussion about Russian hacking into the DNC mail servers has a surreal touch. Anyone who knows Ed Snowden's story has every reason to believe that within the NSA and its affiliate companies there might be dozens, or even hundreds of "super users" who could, if they wanted, surrepetitiously breakt into those mail servers and copy masses of e-mail messages. These guys could probably even plant misleading leads to foreign domains so as to cover their footprints and shift the blame to others. Any meaningful investigation of these leaks should not start with blaming one randomly selected suspect but with determining who had the capabilities to hack those servers, followed by determining who had the motives to do so. We can certainly agree that the Russians had the motives but did they have the capabilities? This is obviously taken for granted by most, so nobody demands presentation of any evidence as to how they did it. If, on the other hand, dozens of NSA "super users" had the capabilities, we can be pretty sure that some among those digital wizards would have had sympathies for Trump and thus would have had the motive to hurt the Clinton campaign. Why are Russian hackers the only candidates that are seriously considered as suspects? Just because the alternate case would be embarrassing for the NSA?

replies.commentBody: *45 doesn't know what taking an oath means. So, he has broken his every 15 seconds since he took it, and thinks that is normal. Since his "base" doesn't either, so they are on his side still. Wonder if they will try to switch sides when we come to get them? Or go to their own trials/hangings never understanding?

comments.commentBody: If Trump and his supporters were shouting, "LOCK HER UP!" because Hillary used a non government email server even though there was no evidence that it was ever hacked or any classified material was exposed, then why aren't they shouting "LOCK THEM UP!" when not only did Sessions  and others meet with the Russians but then they lied about it UNDER OATH to Congress?

It's naive of Trump and his supporters to blame the "Russian" leaks on Obama.  After all, it is Trump openly fawning for more than a year over Putin that brings us here, simply because he one time called Trump "brilliant" (real translation:  a bright star on the political horizon).  Of course, Trump has Russian ties (he fawns, then protests overly much about his connection deluding himself into thinking that Putin thinks highly of him).  Hardly sentimental, ex-KGB Putin more likely sees Trump as a lightweight "patsy" he can manipulate.  He what he's doing to America--divide and conquer, then weaken its sphere of influence and enhancing Russia's role on the international stage with only China to deal with.  America has backed away from any challenge to China, i.e., Trump rejecting the TPP, rejecting his border neighbors (i.e. NAFTA)--very short-sighted strategies. Meanwhile, Trump will tout his domestic agenda, giving corporate tax breaks aimed to keep his billionaire friends happy and deluding his power base with promises he cannot keep (i.e., coal-mining returning), spending billions on the military at the expense of "domestic programs" (code for dropping social needs of the poor and middle-class).  All of this leaves the American people, those who voted for him and those who didn't, high and dry.  Sad (as Trump would say), but more so, bleak.
Well,  well,  well,  what about the millions given

replies.commentBody:
Nobody is claiming that the Russians "hacked" into a voting machine or a polling location, or did you and Rush miss that? The Russians have been identified by the intelligence community as the ones behind the hacking of the DNC and HRC campaign emails and disseminating them through WikiLeaks to sway gullible, low-information voters into voting for this Uber clown car driver of a President.

And we don't need a tool to undermine his legitimacy. He does that all on his own, every time he launches yet another petty tweet.

First of all, you're referring to Russia changing votes, but what is being talked about is the hacking into DNC, and then releasing info and changing info leaked to create a no confidence on Hilary Clinton. Whether or not that actually helped Trump win is a different question, but the act of interfering is still there, and whether or not the Trump's campaign new about it or not needs to be found out. Either way confidence in the US is shaken, and Trump's administration has not helped that view, hindering and name calling doesn't help the truth. Now this maybe because of lack of experience in government and the law.

maisany: Thanks for taking the time to read and to respond to my post.  Sure, you are correct to some extent. The most scrupulous purveyors of the hacking story do not mention hacking elections, but  they leave that to listeners to  make to the connection to elections. Neat indeed!

comments.commentBody: The Russian hacking story has become a tool for those who want to undermine the legitimacy of Mr.  Trump's election, according to Rush Limbaugh, and his  reasoning is persuasive. It is well known that US elections are decentralized, and therefore, changing the results on a large scale through intrusion is impossible.  According to Mr. Limbaugh, those pushing the Russian hacking know this, but it is in their interest to have the American people believe otherwise, but instead, will believe the Russians "elected" Mr. Trump.

replies.commentBody: How much different is it that funds from Russia poured into the Clinton Foundation, while Clinton was SOS, and access to American uranium was up for grabs? Seems the foolish left-wing refuses to see the evidence...accusations like this cuts both ways.

That charge has been debunked.  Maybe, someday you Trump supporters will learn that in REALITY Clinton did no such thing but there is plenty of evidence already that Trump has Russia connections.  And if he doesn't....why won't he release his tax returns?

Dawn, we know about the Russian money to the Clinton Foundation because it was reported, as required by law, by the Foundation.

Trump refuses to release his taxes. There are smoking guns all over the place about his indebtedness to Russian banks. His tax returns could clear this up in 34 hours. Hmmmmm.

comments.commentBody: Trump is owned by the Russians, but the foolish right-wing refuses to see the evidence,   After his bankruptcy, he could not attract American investors.  Russia poured money into and controlled his company.  A company that built government housing -- up and down the East Coast,

comments.commentBody: The "trail of intelligence" left by Obama aides probably allowed the Russians to know from whom and how our IC was getting their intel that was covered ad nauseaum in media.  Soon after the public disclosure of this intel several high Russian officials disappeared.  And it was all political; don't even try to cloak this political intel disclosures in patriotism.  The US has interfered in other countries politics for a long time, including the most recent Russian presidential election, inciting street demonstrations against Putin.  This is hard ball geopolitics and likely explains why Putin dislikes Hillary Clinton, whose State Dept. was up to its eyeballs in those anti-Putin demonstrations.

replies.commentBody:
1. Perhaps it was unwise and unsecure but if Abedin used a browser on Weiner's PC to check her emails via a web interface, it's quite possible that some messages would've been left behind in the cached data. However, it should be pointed out that the FBI indicated quite quickly that whatever might've been on the computer was not actionable, so unless you have further evidence, this is a non-story (a *real* non-story).

2. This is diplomatic tit-for-tat 101. Why is this a mystery to you?

Simply, a concerted and conscious effort is required to set up an e-mail account; various e-mail accounts require specific data files that are stored as *.pst files. I think you are confusing browser cookies and cahed or browser history info.

As I noted she dissavowed any knowledge of how they came to be there. That is the question I raised.

Agree it was a tit-for-tat. My point was wait until days before leaving office? It could just as easily have been done anytime, including when the first allegations/suspicions of Russian hacking/influence became public knowledge. Moreover, given that President Obama purportedly had off-line discussions with Putin back in Sept. or October regarding these very same security/interference issues speaks to the spirit of my question. And at its worst, the action could be cosntrued as incitinga tit-for-tat response just when the new administration was coming into office. Now how diabolical would it be if the intent was to replicate Erdogan's response to the Gulenists?!
[FYI: revisit the times article "After Failed Coup, Turkey Enjoys a Rare Period of Unity" [http://nyti.ms/2bwv315]; play devils advocate and switch the names - both ways - and tell me its not frightening. [Disclosure: I was in Istanbul for months several years ago when the crescendo for Erdogan's autocratic rule was manifesting itself to the locals and was a portend what followed.]

As they say look BOTHways before crossing the street.

Simply, a concerted and conscious effort is required to set up an e-mail account; various e-mail accounts require specific data files that are stored as *.pst files. I think you are confusing browser cookies and cahed or browser history info.

As I noted she dissavowed any knowledge of how they came to be there. That is the question I raised.

Agree it was a tit-for-tat. My point was wait until days before leaving office? It could just as easily have been done anytime, including when the first allegations/suspicions of Russian hacking/influence became public knowledge. Moreover, given that President Obama purportedly had off-line discussions with Putin back in Sept. or October regarding these very same security/interference issues speaks to the spirit of my question. And at its worst, the action could be cosntrued as incitinga tit-for-tat response just when the new administration was coming into office. [FYI: revisit the times article "After Failed Coup, Turkey Enjoys a Rare Period of Unity" [http://nyti.ms/2bwv315]; play devils advocate and switch the names - both ways - and tell me its not frightening. comments.commentBody:
The onslaught is Orwellian at its core. Having immigrated from a former communist country decades ago I can empathasize with onyones concersn about subverting our Democracy to Putin/Russia.

But this is what i find so troublesome:
1. How is that we know more about alledged/purported Trump-Russia commu7nications yet NOn ONE has explained how the Clinton/Abedin e-mails got on a laptop belonging to Abedin’s estranged husband, Anthony D. Weiner. [She coulkdn't explain it or has that changed?]
2. Does not anyone find it curious that the two Russian Compounds, which have been in existence for decades, are revealed/designated in late December 2016 as "spy nests." Are we to believe that for the preceding 7 yrs, 11 months, and 28 days the were "well behaved" or that U.S. Intelligence was unaware of their activities.? ["On Thursday, Obama administration officials described the compounds differently: as beachside [sic] spy nests sometimes used by Russian intelligence operatives to have long conversations on the sand to avoid being ensnared by American electronic surveillance." in https://nyti.ms/2hxQunJ]

A quick look at a calendar will show the expulsions nearly two months after the election! Although undeniably cynical, no DACA for the kids - in the middle of their school term - of the expelled families?

By all means investigate, but do so across the board. Anonymous sources are suspect if not pure wind.

replies.commentBody: Still using that debunked tale of taking the "w"s off of keyboards?  Oh yeah....you guys on the Right don't have any facts, do you?

comments.commentBody: Not surprising given the outgoing administration's view of Trump.  When Bush won, they pried the Ws off the keyboards.  If there was any truth to the allegations,  the liberal media would have crucified Trump.

The revelation of the (ahem) classified "dossier" struck some observers as a mechanism for pressing national security interests into the service of political ends. Now we have confirmation of what was reasonable to suspect: the scurrulity buck did not stop with doing the then President-elect the favor of letting him in on the Intel.

And, lo and behold, here we are. Memo to oppositions operators: less is more. A little highly placed innuendo might have been twice as effective as this blitzkrieg. Just sayin'.

replies.commentBody:
Other than oil and gas what else could we buy? Vodka?

I see no reason to do anything to help them get back into the " Great Game" that they and the British Empire played back in the 19th century with control of Central Asia and the eastern part of the Ottoman Empire. Putin wants Russia's empire back.

There is no reason to help him. At all, in any way.

And as to China Wall Street, Mitt Romney and Co sold America's industrial capacity to them for their own profit and ends. Don't buy Chinese or at least attempt to buy American.
It's getting too easy ... you Russian millennials trying to make a buck need to cultivate a bit more Yankee attitude to make what you are selling credible.

comments.commentBody:
It is sad to read all this hostility towards Trump, Russia and Putin. In a situation that the U.S. are in need of work and income; why not do business with Russia? Or do we still want to support the Chinese economy, to end up in a war with China? Why weaken Russia; who could be our best allied in a conflict with China?

Seen from the intelligence; where, and with whom will we have our next conflict? When will North Korea fall? Who wants NK? The U.S. certainly, but also China and Russia. Japan don't want China to take over NK, neither do U.S. and Russia.

Russia borders to NK with just a few miles, which also parts China from access to Sea of Japan, near the Russian Navy in Vladivostok, and China wants access to Sea of Japan! This is a future great area of conflict, having a huge impact also on the U.S. This is a far larger risk for a greater conflict in this area, than that rather little incident in the Ukraine, which more looks like a decoy for a lot else.

Keeping a good relation with Russia; buy from them so they could be able to buy from us, would far more ensure future wealth and prosperity for the Americans, than keeping Russia as an enemy. The Russian military is still a shadow of its past, but they grow, so be nearer to follow the growth. Many have tried to "starve out" the Russians, but none has yet managed, so why try to challenge that? Why not be friends with Russia? Russia has great people who won't stab us from behind, if we respect them and treat them well.

"What intensified the alarm at the Obama White House was a campaign of cyberattacks on state electoral systems in September, which led the administration to deliver a public accusation against the Russians in October."

If this is true, what possible justification can there be for failing to audit the results of every state's results? These are attacks on electoral systems, not on campaign personnel.
Will no one rid me of this turbulent priest?”
It all makes sense now. No wonder Trump kept talking about a "rigged election", he was projecting his own duplicity onto the other candidate. Oh America, what hast thou done unto thyself?
When will Trump resign?
